review_title: Practice Meritocracy. Identify/reward/retain the people that can bring the group to the next level
pros:
- If you enjoy a laid back environment. this is the place. Not that there is no work to be done, there sure is plenty as certain people in here know how to help in the process to create 'jobs' to be done.
- Generally you can find friendly people to work with in here.
- Average compensation better than SMEs.
cons:
- Meritocracy is non-existence. Middle mgmt care less about who is competent but who they 'like'.
- Generally the standard of the middle mgmt is poor, so I don't blame them for not having much of good leadership behavior and management skills.
- 'Manage up' is all important in here and embedd in the culture, people are too concern impressing senior leader. By way of impressing, I'm not saying through way of adding real value and driving measureable results.
- In whole, my experience is that the analyst (some are really amatuers to be termed an analyst) and AVP levels are overated.. VPs generally are subject matter experts (more like an AVP rank to me), they really need to develop their leadership/ general management skill.

review_title: C2E is a nightmare. don't join Hack2Hire

HR is no use. I think HR needs to take  training first then organize training for us. They are doing only one thing - flattering the senior leader so that they can get promoted ( which hapens always) this company doesnt derseve good people.

when few people speak up against the wrong things, they get thrown out. I know such people who are suffering. Mr Mohit Kapoor who was good and modest is also leaving and now we will have more control from SG and these random C2E leaders who have no values or humbleness at all.

review_title: Great employee benefit, good work life balance but very ineffective internal process.
pros:
- Open space work environment
- Web-Based Learning is really good
- Everything is in the internet so you can use the office wifi to connect your laptop, move around the office and yet still be able to access almost everything you need.
- You can dress smart casual (no tee shirt of course)
- Lots to learn especially if you come from local bank with little to no global banking exposure.
- Really great employee benefit.They do really take care of their employee.
cons:
- Silo interaction between department.
- Layers of regulation within and between department can be very confusing and feels disconnected.
- All the data you need are in the system but you need to access them one by one and interpret them manually just to produce one report, which make a simple work become more frustrating than it should be.
- Too many chains of process which greatly slowdown the process.

review_title: Think before you join.. Money is not everything..
pros:
- Good infrastructure and facility.
- Transport facility.
- More cash in hand.

Positives for some people.
- If you are good in marketing yourself(means you really dont do anything but know how to show that you doing great) then this is the place for you.
- If you can play political games in the team, then this is the place for you. You can sharpen and test your strategies.
- You will get promoted even if you are unprofessional, dumb, can't talk properly, can't write proper emails, don't know technology. Infact you should have one of these qualities to be qualified for a promotion. All of them are a bonus.
- Oh yeah, buttering works. Really well.
cons:
- No proper framework to assess the individual during appraisal. People rate you based on their perception. No objectivity in rating people. 
- The leadership and HR blindly believe the marketing people only(people who don't really work but do show off).
- People in the top management also show  regional and language bias.
- HR people do not understand what is happening on the ground and blindly believe the senior management.

pros:
Such a slow pace of work that you can balance other commitments.
No one ever gets fired, no matter how useless.
Singapore exposure
Great office at Nariman point- the view is outstanding from the higher floors and the seating is agile (not fixed)
cons:
A lot of the HR policies are just on paper- they sell them to you when you are joining. Example: Flexi-time and Work from home. In reality the managers rarely approve any of these. HR is a huge team which is largely incompetent- not sure which gutter they hire them from. None of the HR working at DBS would be employable elsewhere.
The India managing committee is a mixed bag. The heads of the business functions are jokers, some of the support function like finance and legal are fine- but marketing and HR are really sub-standard.
Singapore interferes (and often creates a mess) in India functioning. 
Too many tedious, unnecessary processes which slow down everything

review_title: DAH 2 should be your worst case option to join.
pros: I didn't see it has any additional or unique benefits than  any other product based company.
cons:
No work Life balance. 
Too much micro management.
Not flexible in the matter of timings.
No work from home.
You better ignore joining here even though you get the best package because if you join, soon you'll realize what biggest mistake you made.. :). 
Not suitable especially for the married folks.
You will definitely feel that you got stuck because for your experience DAH 2 hr knows that opportunities will be less outside . That's why they prefer to recruit more experienced folks , generally 7+yrs.
Luckily I have realized early and moved out and there is no single day at DAH 2 where I went to office with a whole hearted smile.
Follow fail-fast principle to quit from here or else you will stuck forever. 
This is from my personal experience, if you still want to feel how it will be in DAH 2... It's up to you... :). Good luck from your well wisher.. :)

pros:
Nice infrastructure if you work as a direct employee.
They are evolving with new Technologies.
cons:
Poor Project Management in development. They say agile but they don't exactly follow agile. 
Difficult understanding what people from Singapore say during requirement gathering.
No respect if you work as a vendor. 
No work life balance. Production Support job is very stressful. They say on call and do not pay if there isn't a production Incident which means that you have to be at home waiting for SMS alert. There is no shift planning in some teams and you will be called anytime by DBS Leads.
No work from home option because of regulatory reasons but India is not Singapore where you get MRT anytime. No Google access in ODCs which means you won't be able to read Technical Stuff sometimes if you want to.

review_title: Horrible experience, did absolutely NOTHING to my career growth
pros:
- Decent wage
- Some hardworking, talented and genuinely good people.
cons:
- NO work-life balance, CRAZY workload.    
- Terrible/unprofessional leadership - its not what you know but WHO you know.  Dodges responsiblities but will not hesitate to take YOUR credit as their own when reporting to the higher authorities.
-Very political, it is always the SAME group of people doing overtime, and the same group of people leading a healthy, happy normal life. 
  - Training given to new hires is a JOKE - jot down as much notes as humanly possible while your trainers go full speed at demonstrating his/her daily tasks, of which will become yours once this training session is over.  Oh, and the notes that you just jotted down become the official SOP since there was NONE!!!!!
- High turnover rate (a total of 8 ppl quit during my first 3 months)

pros: Decent pay, cab facility, understanding teammates, decent stack, active upper management & active HR teams.
cons:
The company is in a middle of a transition from it's core old banking firm to a more technical mindset firm. This transition isn't uniform, some departments are way ahead in the migration than few others.  

In respect to my department: 

1. Lack of challenging CS problems. 
2. Drastic code/scope changes will require Singapore management involvement which stops you as an engineer from truly making a great product.  
3. Sometimes monotonous work.
4. Poor timings & No work from home. 

DBS will slowly but surely transition into a proper tech company however most employees rightly so, wouldn't want to wait that long.

review_title: Organisation is good place for growth
pros: Hardwork pays off in DBS with extremely good promotion and recognition with top management including interviews with the ceo and team bonding exercises with leadership. Right place to be if you want due recognition and opportunity for fast track growth.
cons: Fairly new in the wealth management market. DBS Bank Strategy is a bit confusing for general customer who may be looking for an all solutions provider or complete banking package. DBs needs to refocus on its core competencies to outline and postion itself on a significant market share.
